title: Eddie Jones ‘saves job’ by guiding England to Rugby World Cup semi-final
text:
The Australian coach has another two years left on his England contract (Picture: Getty)

Eddie Jones will not be subject to a reported break clause in his contract that would have allowed the RFU to sack him after the Rugby World Cup.

Jones’ England thrashed Australia 40-16 in Oita to reach the semi-finals where they will face either Ireland or New Zealand for a place in the final.

The Australian coach, appointed in the wake of the 2015 debacle where England were eliminated at the group stage, is said to have been set a minimum goal of the last four at the tournament this time around.

And according to the Daily Mail, the RFU would have been able to terminate his contract despite having two years left to run.

The 59-year-old signed an extension in January 2018 ahead of the Six Nations and could remain until halfway through the next World Cup cycle under the current deal.

Jones was even linked with a move away from the job irrespective of the results in Japan but he himself has always been clear that he wants to stay on within the England set-up.

Never one to shy away from a bold decision, Jones put his reputation on the line with his starting XV against Australia, dropping George Ford to the bench to bring in Henry Slade for his first start of the Rugby World Cup.

The centre flew to Japan carrying a long-term injury but showed no rust against Australia, intercepting the ball and hitting a deft kick through for Jonny May to score the second try of the game.

Henry Slade’s inclusion and Owen Farrell’s move to 10 was an Eddie Jones masterstroke (Picture: Getty)

Jones was also pleased with the decision to move Owen Farrell up to fly-half before introducing Ford as the game broke down in the second half.

‘Without trying to be too clever, that’s how we thought the game would go,’ Jones said afterwards, feeling vindicated in his decision-making.

‘[We thought] the first 30 or 40 [minutes] would be really physical with a lot of defence and Owen is definitely our best defensive 10.

‘Then we thought the second half would be more open and George Ford came on and was absolutely brilliant for us.’
